1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Schaff Trend Cycle (STC)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// An oscillator that cycles between 0 and 100 with lower lag than MACD.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>Combines MACD and Stochastic logic.</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>Detects trends earlier and avoids whipsaws better than MACD.</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>Buy Signal: Crosses above 25.</description></item>
15 /// <item><description>Sell Signal: Crosses below 75.</description></item>
16 /// </list>
17 /// </remarks>
18 public class SchaffTrendCycle
19 {
20 public int MACDShort { get; }
21 public int MACDLong { get; }
22 public int CyclePeriod { get; }
23 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
24​
25 public SchaffTrendCycle(int macdShort = 23, int macdLong = 50, int cyclePeriod = 10)
26 {
27 MACDShort = macdShort;
28 MACDLong = macdLong;
29 CyclePeriod = cyclePeriod;
30 }
31​
32 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
33 {
34 Values.Clear();
35 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
36 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
37​
38 var macd = CalculateMACD(candleList, MACDShort, MACDLong);
39​
40 // Stoch 1 of MACD
41 var stoch1 = CalculateStoch(macd, CyclePeriod);
42 // Smooth Stoch 1
43 var smoothedStoch1 = EmaSmooth(stoch1, 3);
44
45 // Stoch 2 of Smoothed Stoch 1
46 var stoch2 = CalculateStoch(smoothedStoch1, CyclePeriod);
47
48 // Final Smooth Stoch 2 -> STC
49 var stc = EmaSmooth(stoch2, 3);
50​
51 foreach (var v in stc)
52 Values.Add(v.HasValue ? Math.Max(0, Math.Min(100, v.Value)) : null);
53 }
54​
55 private static List<decimal?> CalculateStoch(List<decimal?> input, int period)
56 {
57 var results = new List<decimal?>();
58 for (int i = 0; i < input.Count; i++)
59 {
60 if (i < period - 1 || !input[i].HasValue)
61 {
62 results.Add(null);
63 continue;
64 }
65​
66 decimal highest = decimal.MinValue;
67 decimal lowest = decimal.MaxValue;
68 bool valid = true;
69
70 for (int j = i - period + 1; j <= i; j++)
71 {
72 if (!input[j].HasValue) { valid = false; break; }
73 if (input[j]!.Value > highest) highest = input[j]!.Value;
74 if (input[j]!.Value < lowest) lowest = input[j]!.Value;
75 }
76​
77 if (!valid) { results.Add(null); continue; }
78​
79 if (highest == lowest)
80 results.Add(0);
81 else
82 results.Add((input[i]!.Value - lowest) / (highest - lowest) * 100);
83 }
84 return results;
85 }
86​
87 private static List<decimal?> CalculateMACD(List<CandleData> candles, int shortPeriod, int longPeriod)
88 {
89 var shortEma = CalculateEma(candles, shortPeriod);
90 var longEma = CalculateEma(candles, longPeriod);
91 var macd = new List<decimal?>();
92
93 for (int i = 0; i < candles.Count; i++)
94 {
95 if (shortEma[i].HasValue && longEma[i].HasValue)
96 macd.Add(shortEma[i]!.Value - longEma[i]!.Value);
97 else
98 macd.Add(null);
99 }
100 return macd;
101 }
102​
103 private static List<decimal?> CalculateEma(List<CandleData> candles, int period)
104 {
105 var results = new List<decimal?>();
106 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
107 decimal? prevEma = null;
108​
109 for (int i = 0; i < candles.Count; i++)
110 {
111 if (i < period - 1) { results.Add(null); continue; }
112 if (i == period - 1)
113 {
114 decimal sum = 0;
115 for (int j = 0; j < period; j++) sum += candles[i - j].Close;
116 prevEma = sum / period;
117 results.Add(prevEma);
118 continue;
119 }
120 if (prevEma != null)
121 {
122 decimal ema = (candles[i].Close - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
123 results.Add(ema);
124 prevEma = ema;
125 }
126 else results.Add(null);
127 }
128 return results;
129 }
130​
131 private static List<decimal?> EmaSmooth(List<decimal?> source, int period)
132 {
133 var results = new List<decimal?>();
134 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
135 decimal? prev = null;
136 int validCount = 0;
137​
138 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
139 {
140 if (!source[i].HasValue) { results.Add(null); continue; }
141 validCount++;
142 if (validCount == 1) { prev = source[i]; results.Add(prev); continue; }
143
144 if (prev.HasValue)
145 {
146 decimal v = (source[i]!.Value - prev.Value) * k + prev.Value;
147 results.Add(v);
148 prev = v;
149 }
150 else results.Add(null);
151 }
152 return results;
153 }
154​
155 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int macdShort = 23, int macdLong = 50, int cyclePeriod = 10)
156 {
157 var stc = new SchaffTrendCycle(macdShort, macdLong, cyclePeriod);
158 stc.Calculate(candles);
159 return stc.Values;
160 }
161 }
162}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (SchaffTrendCycle)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Schaff Trend Cycle (STC) indicator. We explain *why* code is written
7// this way and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting beginners.
8//
9// [Core Concepts]
10// 1. MACD Foundation
11// STC starts with classic MACD (Short EMA - Long EMA) to capture momentum.
12// [Why] MACD detects trend direction but reacts slowly to price changes.
13//
14// 2. Double Stochastic Transformation
15// Apply Stochastic normalization twice to compress MACD into 0-100 range.
16// [Why] Double application increases responsiveness and reduces noise.
17//
18// 3. EMA Smoothing Between Stages
19// Each Stochastic output is smoothed with a 3-period EMA.
20// [Why] Prevents whipsaws from noisy Stochastic values.
21//
22// 4. Final Output Clamping
23// Values are clamped to [0, 100] range for consistent interpretation.
24// [Why] Ensures oscillator stays within standard overbought/oversold bounds.
25//
26// [Visual] STC Calculation Pipeline:
27//
28// ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
29// │ Price Data │
30// │ │ │
31// │ ▼ │
32// │ ┌─────────────┐ ┌─────────────┐ │
33// │ │ Short EMA │ │ Long EMA │ │
34// │ │ (period=23) │ │ (period=50) │ │
35// │ └──────┬──────┘ └──────┬──────┘ │
36// │ │ │ │
37// │ └────────┬────────┘ │
38// │ ▼ │
39// │ ┌───────────────┐ │
40// │ │ MACD Line │ = ShortEMA - LongEMA │
41// │ └───────┬───────┘ │
42// │ ▼ │
43// │ ┌───────────────┐ │
44// │ │ Stochastic #1 │ = (MACD - Low) / (High - Low) × 100 │
45// │ └───────┬───────┘ │
46// │ ▼ │
47// │ ┌───────────────┐ │
48// │ │ EMA Smooth │ (period=3) │
49// │ └───────┬───────┘ │
50// │ ▼ │
51// │ ┌───────────────┐ │
52// │ │ Stochastic #2 │ = (Smooth1 - Low) / (High - Low) × 100│
53// │ └───────┬───────┘ │
54// │ ▼ │
55// │ ┌───────────────┐ │
56// │ │ EMA Smooth │ (period=3) │
57// │ └───────┬───────┘ │
58// │ ▼ │
59// │ ┌───────────────┐ │
60// │ │ Clamp [0,100] │ → Final STC Output │
61// │ └───────────────┘ │
62// └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
63//
64// [Trading Signals]
65// - STC > 75: Overbought zone (potential sell)
66// - STC < 25: Oversold zone (potential buy)
67// - Cross above 25 from below: Buy signal
68// - Cross below 75 from above: Sell signal
69//
70// =============================================================================
71​
72using System;
73using System.Collections.Generic;
74​
75namespace TechnicalIndicators
76{
77 // =========================================================================
78 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container (CandleData)
79 // =========================================================================
80 //
81 // [Why]
82 // Standardized price data representation for all technical indicators.
83 //
84 // [What]
85 // Encapsulates: Timestamp, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume
86 //
87 // [Where]
88 // Stack allocation (readonly record struct) for performance.
89 // Value semantics ensure immutability and efficient memory usage.
90 //
91 // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
92 public readonly record struct CandleData(
93 DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High,
94 decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume
95 );
96​
97 // =========================================================================
98 // Logic Explanation: Schaff Trend Cycle Indicator
99 // =========================================================================
100 //
101 // [Why]
102 // Doug Schaff developed STC to address MACD's lag problem.
103 // By applying double Stochastic transformation, STC reacts faster
104 // to trend changes while filtering out noise.
105 //
106 // [What]
107 // Combines MACD momentum with Stochastic oscillator normalization.
108 // Output: Oscillator values in 0-100 range.
109 //
110 // [Who]
111 // - Trend traders: Direction confirmation
112 // - Swing traders: Overbought/oversold signals
113 // - Momentum traders: Early trend detection
114 //
115 // [Where]
116 // Heap allocation (class) because it holds output collection and
117 // requires multiple helper method calls.
118 //
119 // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
120 public class SchaffTrendCycle
121 {
122 // =====================================================================
123 // Logic Explanation: Indicator Configuration (Public Properties)
124 // =====================================================================
125 //
126 // [Why]
127 // Three parameters control STC behavior:
128 // - MACDShort: Fast EMA responsiveness
129 // - MACDLong: Slow EMA baseline
130 // - CyclePeriod: Stochastic lookback window
131 //
132 // [What]
133 // Default values (23, 50, 10) are Doug Schaff's original settings.
134 // Different from MACD defaults (12, 26) for longer-term cycles.
135 //
136 // [Who]
137 // Set by user at construction, read by Calculate method.
138 //
139 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
140​
141 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
142 // Variable Definition: Short EMA Period
143 // public int MACDShort { get; }
144 //
145 // [Role]
146 // Period for the fast (short) EMA in MACD calculation.
147 // Shorter period = more reactive to recent prices.
148 //
149 // [Type Choice]
150 // int: Count of bars. Read-only after construction.
151 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
152 public int MACDShort { get; }
153​
154 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
155 // Variable Definition: Long EMA Period
156 // public int MACDLong { get; }
157 //
158 // [Role]
159 // Period for the slow (long) EMA in MACD calculation.
160 // Longer period = smoother baseline trend.
161 //
162 // [Type Choice]
163 // int: Count of bars. Must be greater than MACDShort.
164 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
165 public int MACDLong { get; }
166​
167 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
168 // Variable Definition: Stochastic Cycle Period
169 // public int CyclePeriod { get; }
170 //
171 // [Role]
172 // Lookback period for both Stochastic calculations.
173 // Determines how many bars to scan for highest/lowest values.
174 //
175 // [Type Choice]
176 // int: Count of bars. Default 10 captures typical market cycles.
177 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
178 public int CyclePeriod { get; }
179​
180 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
181 // Variable Definition: Output Values
182 // public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
183 //
184 // [Role]
185 // Stores computed STC values. Range: 0-100.
186 // null = insufficient data (warm-up period).
187 //
188 // [Type Choice]
189 // List<decimal?>: Dynamic size, nullable for warm-up.
190 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
191 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
192​
193 // =====================================================================
194 // Logic Explanation: Constructor
195 // =====================================================================
196 //
197 // [Why]
198 // Stores user-provided or default parameters.
199 // Note: Original STC does not validate parameters (no Fail Fast).
200 //
201 // [What]
202 // Simply assigns parameters to properties.
203 //
204 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
205 public SchaffTrendCycle(int macdShort = 23, int macdLong = 50, int cyclePeriod = 10)
206 {
207 MACDShort = macdShort;
208 MACDLong = macdLong;
209 CyclePeriod = cyclePeriod;
210 }
211​
212 // =====================================================================
213 // IPO: Calculate
214 // =====================================================================
215 //
216 // [Input]
217 // - candles: IEnumerable<CandleData> - OHLCV price bars
218 //
219 // [Process]
220 // 1. Calculate MACD line (ShortEMA - LongEMA)
221 // 2. Apply first Stochastic transformation
222 // 3. Smooth with 3-period EMA
223 // 4. Apply second Stochastic transformation
224 // 5. Smooth with 3-period EMA and clamp to [0, 100]
225 //
226 // [Output]
227 // - Populates Values list with STC oscillator values
228 //
229 // =====================================================================
230 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
231 {
232 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
233 // Logic Step 1: Clear Previous Results
234 //
235 // [Why] Reset state for recalculation
236 // [How] Remove all previous values
237 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
238 Values.Clear();
239​
240 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
241 // Logic Step 2: Materialize and Guard
242 //
243 // [Why] Need indexed access for lookback operations
244 // [How] Convert IEnumerable to List, exit if empty
245 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
246 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
247 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
248​
249 // =================================================================
250 // Logic Step 3: Calculate MACD Line
251 // =================================================================
252 //
253 // [Why]
254 // MACD forms the foundation of STC. It measures the gap between
255 // fast and slow EMAs, indicating momentum direction.
256 //
257 // [How]
258 // MACD = EMA(Close, ShortPeriod) - EMA(Close, LongPeriod)
259 //
260 // [Visual]
261 // Price: 100 102 105 103 108
262 // ShortEMA: null null ... 102 103.5
263 // LongEMA: null null ... null null ... (waits longer)
264 // MACD: null null ... null +2.5 (when both valid)
265 //
266 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
267 var macd = CalculateMACD(candleList, MACDShort, MACDLong);
268​
269 // =================================================================
270 // Logic Step 4: First Stochastic Transformation
271 // =================================================================
272 //
273 // [Why]
274 // Normalize MACD into 0-100 range using Stochastic formula.
275 // This shows where current MACD stands relative to recent range.
276 //
277 // [How]
278 // Stoch1 = (MACD - LowestMACD) / (HighestMACD - LowestMACD) × 100
279 //
280 // [Visual]
281 // MACD values in window: [-2, 0, 3, 5, 2]
282 // Highest = 5, Lowest = -2, Range = 7
283 // Current MACD = 2
284 // Stoch1 = (2 - (-2)) / 7 × 100 = 57.14%
285 //
286 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
287 var stoch1 = new List<decimal?>();
288 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
289 {
290 // -------------------------------------------------------------
291 // Logic Step 4.1: Check Warm-Up Period
292 //
293 // [Decision] Has enough data for Stochastic calculation?
294 // [True: Insufficient] Output null and continue
295 // [False: Sufficient] Proceed to calculation
296 // -------------------------------------------------------------
297 if (i < CyclePeriod - 1 || !macd[i].HasValue)
298 {
299 stoch1.Add(null);
300 continue;
301 }
302​
303 // -------------------------------------------------------------
304 // Logic Step 4.2: Find Highest and Lowest in Window
305 //
306 // [Why] Stochastic needs range boundaries
307 // [How] Scan CyclePeriod bars to find min/max
308 //
309 // [Visual] Sliding Window for Stochastic:
310 // Index: 0 1 2 3 4 5 6
311 // MACD: [-2] [0] [3] [5] [2] [1] [4]
312 // └─────────────────┘
313 // Window at i=4
314 // (CyclePeriod=4)
315 // -------------------------------------------------------------
316 decimal highest = decimal.MinValue, lowest = decimal.MaxValue;
317 for (int j = i - CyclePeriod + 1; j <= i; j++)
318 {
319 if (macd[j].HasValue)
320 {
321 if (macd[j]!.Value > highest) highest = macd[j]!.Value;
322 if (macd[j]!.Value < lowest) lowest = macd[j]!.Value;
323 }
324 }
325​
326 // -------------------------------------------------------------
327 // Logic Step 4.3: Calculate Stochastic Value
328 //
329 // [Decision] Is the range zero (highest == lowest)?
330 // [True: Zero Range] Output 0 to avoid division by zero
331 // [False: Valid Range] Apply Stochastic formula
332 // -------------------------------------------------------------
333 stoch1.Add(highest == lowest ? 0 : (macd[i]!.Value - lowest) / (highest - lowest) * 100);
334 }
335​
336 // =================================================================
337 // Logic Step 5: Smooth First Stochastic with EMA
338 // =================================================================
339 //
340 // [Why]
341 // Raw Stochastic values are noisy. EMA smoothing reduces
342 // false signals while preserving responsiveness.
343 //
344 // [How]
345 // SmoothedStoch1 = EMA(Stoch1, 3)
346 // 3-period EMA is fast enough to keep STC responsive.
347 //
348 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
349 var smoothedStoch1 = EmaSmooth(stoch1, 3);
350​
351 // =================================================================
352 // Logic Step 6: Second Stochastic Transformation
353 // =================================================================
354 //
355 // [Why]
356 // Double Stochastic further compresses the range and
357 // emphasizes extreme readings. This is Doug Schaff's key insight.
358 //
359 // [How]
360 // Same process as Step 4, but applied to smoothedStoch1.
361 //
362 // [Visual] Double Stochastic Effect:
363 // SmoothedStoch1: 40 50 60 70 80 85 90
364 // └────────────────┘
365 // Window
366 // Stoch2 at 90: (90 - 60) / (90 - 60) × 100 = 100%
367 // (Strong overbought signal)
368 //
369 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
370 var stoch2 = new List<decimal?>();
371 for (int i = 0; i < candleList.Count; i++)
372 {
373 // -------------------------------------------------------------
374 // Logic Step 6.1: Check Warm-Up Period
375 // -------------------------------------------------------------
376 if (i < CyclePeriod - 1 || !smoothedStoch1[i].HasValue)
377 {
378 stoch2.Add(null);
379 continue;
380 }
381​
382 // -------------------------------------------------------------
383 // Logic Step 6.2: Find Highest and Lowest in Smoothed Window
384 // -------------------------------------------------------------
385 decimal highest = decimal.MinValue, lowest = decimal.MaxValue;
386 for (int j = i - CyclePeriod + 1; j <= i; j++)
387 {
388 if (smoothedStoch1[j].HasValue)
389 {
390 if (smoothedStoch1[j]!.Value > highest) highest = smoothedStoch1[j]!.Value;
391 if (smoothedStoch1[j]!.Value < lowest) lowest = smoothedStoch1[j]!.Value;
392 }
393 }
394​
395 // -------------------------------------------------------------
396 // Logic Step 6.3: Calculate Second Stochastic
397 // -------------------------------------------------------------
398 stoch2.Add(highest == lowest ? 0 : (smoothedStoch1[i]!.Value - lowest) / (highest - lowest) * 100);
399 }
400​
401 // =================================================================
402 // Logic Step 7: Final Smoothing and Clamping
403 // =================================================================
404 //
405 // [Why]
406 // Final EMA smoothing creates the tradeable signal.
407 // Clamping ensures output stays in expected 0-100 range.
408 //
409 // [How]
410 // STC = Clamp(EMA(Stoch2, 3), 0, 100)
411 //
412 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
413 var stc = EmaSmooth(stoch2, 3);
414 foreach (var v in stc)
415 Values.Add(v.HasValue ? Math.Max(0, Math.Min(100, v.Value)) : null);
416 }
417​
418 // =====================================================================
419 // IPO: CalculateMACD
420 // =====================================================================
421 //
422 // [Input]
423 // - candles: List<CandleData> - Price bars
424 // - shortPeriod: int - Fast EMA period
425 // - longPeriod: int - Slow EMA period
426 //
427 // [Process]
428 // 1. Calculate Short EMA from Close prices
429 // 2. Calculate Long EMA from Close prices
430 // 3. Subtract: MACD = ShortEMA - LongEMA
431 //
432 // [Output]
433 // - List<decimal?> with MACD line values
434 // null when either EMA is not yet valid
435 //
436 // =====================================================================
437 private static List<decimal?> CalculateMACD(List<CandleData> candles, int shortPeriod, int longPeriod)
438 {
439 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
440 // Logic Step 1: Calculate Both EMAs
441 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
442 var shortEma = CalculateEma(candles, shortPeriod);
443 var longEma = CalculateEma(candles, longPeriod);
444​
445 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
446 // Logic Step 2: Compute MACD = Short - Long
447 //
448 // [Visual]
449 // Index: 0 1 ... 22 23 ... 49 50 51
450 // ShortEMA: null null ... null val ... val val val
451 // LongEMA: null null ... null null ... null val val
452 // MACD: null null ... null null ... null val val
453 // ↑
454 // First valid MACD
455 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
456 var macd = new List<decimal?>();
457 for (int i = 0; i < candles.Count; i++)
458 {
459 if (shortEma[i].HasValue && longEma[i].HasValue)
460 macd.Add(shortEma[i]!.Value - longEma[i]!.Value);
461 else
462 macd.Add(null);
463 }
464 return macd;
465 }
466​
467 // =====================================================================
468 // IPO: CalculateEma
469 // =====================================================================
470 //
471 // [Input]
472 // - candles: List<CandleData> - Price bars
473 // - period: int - EMA period
474 //
475 // [Process]
476 // 1. Calculate smoothing factor: k = 2 / (period + 1)
477 // 2. First EMA = SMA of first 'period' values
478 // 3. Subsequent: EMA = (Close - PrevEMA) × k + PrevEMA
479 //
480 // [Output]
481 // - List<decimal?> with EMA values
482 // null during warm-up period (i < period - 1)
483 //
484 // [Visual] EMA Calculation Example:
485 // Period = 3, k = 2/(3+1) = 0.5
486 //
487 // i=0: Close=100 → null (warm-up)
488 // i=1: Close=102 → null (warm-up)
489 // i=2: Close=104 → SMA = (100+102+104)/3 = 102.0 (first EMA)
490 // i=3: Close=103 → EMA = (103-102)×0.5 + 102 = 102.5
491 // i=4: Close=105 → EMA = (105-102.5)×0.5 + 102.5 = 103.75
492 //
493 // =====================================================================
494 private static List<decimal?> CalculateEma(List<CandleData> candles, int period)
495 {
496 var results = new List<decimal?>();
497​
498 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
499 // Variable Definition: Smoothing Factor
500 // decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
501 //
502 // [Role] Weight for new data in EMA formula
503 // [Type Choice] decimal for financial precision
504 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
505 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
506 decimal? prevEma = null;
507​
508 for (int i = 0; i < candles.Count; i++)
509 {
510 // -------------------------------------------------------------
511 // Logic Step 1: Warm-Up Period
512 //
513 // [Decision] Is i < period - 1?
514 // [True] Not enough data for EMA → output null
515 // -------------------------------------------------------------
516 if (i < period - 1) { results.Add(null); continue; }
517​
518 // -------------------------------------------------------------
519 // Logic Step 2: Seed EMA with SMA
520 //
521 // [Decision] Is this exactly the 'period-1' index?
522 // [True] Calculate SMA as initial EMA value
523 // -------------------------------------------------------------
524 if (i == period - 1)
525 {
526 decimal sum = 0;
527 for (int j = 0; j < period; j++) sum += candles[i - j].Close;
528 prevEma = sum / period;
529 results.Add(prevEma);
530 continue;
531 }
532​
533 // -------------------------------------------------------------
534 // Logic Step 3: Running EMA Calculation
535 //
536 // [How] EMA = (Price - PrevEMA) × k + PrevEMA
537 // Equivalent to: EMA = Price × k + PrevEMA × (1 - k)
538 // -------------------------------------------------------------
539 if (prevEma != null)
540 {
541 decimal ema = (candles[i].Close - prevEma.Value) * k + prevEma.Value;
542 results.Add(ema);
543 prevEma = ema;
544 }
545 else results.Add(null);
546 }
547 return results;
548 }
549​
550 // =====================================================================
551 // IPO: EmaSmooth
552 // =====================================================================
553 //
554 // [Input]
555 // - source: List<decimal?> - Nullable value series
556 // - period: int - EMA period (typically 3 for STC)
557 //
558 // [Process]
559 // Apply EMA to nullable series, tracking valid count.
560 // First valid value becomes the initial EMA (no SMA seed).
561 //
562 // [Output]
563 // - List<decimal?> with smoothed values
564 //
565 // [Why No SMA Seed?]
566 // For internal smoothing, using first value as seed is simpler
567 // and still effective for short periods like 3.
568 //
569 // =====================================================================
570 private static List<decimal?> EmaSmooth(List<decimal?> source, int period)
571 {
572 var results = new List<decimal?>();
573 decimal k = 2.0m / (period + 1);
574 decimal? prev = null;
575 int validCount = 0;
576​
577 for (int i = 0; i < source.Count; i++)
578 {
579 // -------------------------------------------------------------
580 // Logic Step 1: Skip Null Values
581 //
582 // [Decision] Is source[i] null?
583 // [True] Propagate null, don't increment validCount
584 // -------------------------------------------------------------
585 if (!source[i].HasValue) { results.Add(null); continue; }
586​
587 validCount++;
588​
589 // -------------------------------------------------------------
590 // Logic Step 2: Initialize with First Valid Value
591 //
592 // [Decision] Is this the first valid value?
593 // [True] Use as initial EMA (no averaging)
594 // -------------------------------------------------------------
595 if (validCount == 1) { prev = source[i]; results.Add(prev); continue; }
596​
597 // -------------------------------------------------------------
598 // Logic Step 3: Apply EMA Formula
599 // -------------------------------------------------------------
600 if (prev.HasValue)
601 {
602 decimal v = (source[i]!.Value - prev.Value) * k + prev.Value;
603 results.Add(v);
604 prev = v;
605 }
606 else results.Add(null);
607 }
608 return results;
609 }

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Schaff Trend Cycle)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Schaff Trend Cycle (STC).
7#
8# [Core Concepts]
9# 1. The Problem with MACD
10# - MACD is great at TREND but useless for precise timing (it lags).
11#
12# 2. The Problem with Stochastics
13# - Stochastics is great at TIMING but terrible at trend (it's noisy and
14# stays overbought for too long).
15#
16# 3. The Solution (STC)
17# - Doug Schaff decided to calculate the Stochastic ... OF the MACD.
18# - Then he Smoothed it.
19# - Then he calculated the Stochastic OF the Smoothed Result.
20# - Then he Smoothed it AGAIN.
21#
22# [Formula Chain]
23# MACD -> Stoch(MACD) -> EMA -> Stoch(RESULT) -> EMA -> STC Value.
24# Result is a clean square-wave oscillator that snaps between 0 and 100.
25#
26# =============================================================================
27​
28# -------------------------------------------------------------
29# Type-Level Explanation: SchaffTrendCycle (class)
30#
31# [Why] Currency trader favorite for reducing false signals.
32# [Why] Currency market cycle detection.
33# [What] Oscillator of an Oscillator.
34# [How] Computes MACD, applies Stochastic logic to it, smooths it, applies Stochastic logic again, and smooths it one last time.
35# [Who] Doug Schaff (2002).
36# -------------------------------------------------------------
37class SchaffTrendCycle:
38
39 # -------------------------------------------------------------
40 # Constructor: __init__
41 # [Why]
42 # - MACD defaults (23, 50) are Schaff's specific cycle/trend settings.
43 # (Different from standard 12, 26).
44 # - Cycle Period (10) determines the lookback for the Stoch calculations.
45 # -------------------------------------------------------------
46 def __init__(self, macd_short=23, macd_long=50, cycle_period=10):
47 self.macd_short = macd_short
48 self.macd_long = macd_long
49 self.cycle_period = cycle_period
50 self.values = []
51​
52 # =============================================================================
53 # IPO: calculate
54 # =============================================================================
55 #
56 # [Input]
57 # - candles: List[dict]
58 #
59 # [Process]
60 # 1. Calc MACD Line.
61 # 2. Calc Stoch %K of MACD (Stoch1).
62 # 3. EMA Smooth Stoch1 (Smoothed1).
63 # 4. Calc Stoch %K of Smoothed1 (Stoch2).
64 # 5. EMA Smooth Stoch2 (Final STC).
65 #
66 # [Output]
67 # - None.
68 # =============================================================================
69 def calculate(self, candles):
70 self.values.clear()
71 if len(candles) == 0:
72 return
73​
74 # -------------------------------------------------------------
75 # Logic Step 1: Base Indicator (MACD)
76 # [Why] Establish the underlying trend momentum.
77 # [How] ShortEMA - LongEMA.
78 # -------------------------------------------------------------
79 macd_line = self._calculate_macd(candles, self.macd_short, self.macd_long)
80​
81 # -------------------------------------------------------------
82 # Logic Step 2: First Stochastic Layer
83 # [Why] Identify the cycle position of the MACD.
84 # [How] (Current - Lowest) / (Highest - Lowest) * 100
85 # -------------------------------------------------------------
86 stoch_1 = self._calculate_stochastic(macd_line, self.cycle_period)
87​
88 # -------------------------------------------------------------
89 # Logic Step 3: First Smoothing Layer
90 # [Why] Reduce initial noise from the raw Stochastic.
91 # [How] Schaff uses a very short EMA (Factor 0.5, approx period 3).
92 # -------------------------------------------------------------
93 smoothed_1 = self._calculate_ema_of_values(stoch_1, 3)
94​
95 # -------------------------------------------------------------
96 # Logic Step 4: Second Stochastic Layer
97 # [Why] Amplify the cyclic signal from the smoothed result.
98 # [How] Apply Stoch Formula again to the Smoothed values.
99 # -------------------------------------------------------------
100 stoch_2 = self._calculate_stochastic(smoothed_1, self.cycle_period)
101​
102 # -------------------------------------------------------------
103 # Logic Step 5: Final Smoothing Layer
104 # [Why] Produce the final clean STC oscillator.
105 # [How] EMA(3) of the Second Stochastic.
106 # -------------------------------------------------------------
107 stc_values = self._calculate_ema_of_values(stoch_2, 3)
108
109 # Clamp output for safety
110 self.values = [max(0, min(100, v)) if v is not None else None for v in stc_values]
111​
112​
113 # =============================================================================
114 # IPO: _calculate_stochastic (Helper)
115 # =============================================================================
116 # [Input] data_stream (list), period (int)
117 # [Process] Sliding window Min/Max. Normalization.
118 # [Output] list[float] (0-100)
119 # =============================================================================
120 def _calculate_stochastic(self, data_stream, period):
121 results = []
122 for i in range(len(data_stream)):
123
124 # Check availability
125 # We need valid data at current index AND valid data 'period' bars back
126 if i < period - 1:
127 results.append(None)
128 continue
129
130 # If current or any in window is None, we can't calculate
131 # (Though in practice only need to check head/tail if contiguous)
132 if data_stream[i] is None:
133 results.append(None)
134 continue
135
136 # Extract Window
137 # Note: We filter out None values just in case, though logic above prevents it mostly
138 window = []
139 valid_window = True
140 for j in range(period):
141 val = data_stream[i - j]
142 if val is None:
143 valid_window = False
144 break
145 window.append(val)
146
147 if not valid_window or not window:
148 results.append(None)
149 continue
150
151 # Compute
152 highest = max(window)
153 lowest = min(window)
154 current = data_stream[i]
155
156 if highest == lowest:
157 # Flat line -> Stoch is 0 (or undefined, we use 0)
158 results.append(0.0)
159 else:
160 k = ((current - lowest) / (highest - lowest)) * 100.0
161 results.append(k)
162
163 return results
164​
165 # =============================================================================
166 # IPO: _calculate_ema_of_values (Helper)
167 # =============================================================================
168 # [Input] data_stream (list), period (int)
169 # [Process] Standard EMA but for generic lists, not Candles.
170 # =============================================================================
171 def _calculate_ema_of_values(self, data_stream, period):
172 results = []
173 alpha = 2.0 / (period + 1.0)
174 ema = None
175
176 for i in range(len(data_stream)):
177 val = data_stream[i]
178
179 if val is None:
180 results.append(None)
181 # If we encounter a gap, do we reset EMA?
182 # Usually yes, or hold previous. We'll reset here for safety.
183 ema = None
184 continue
185
186 if ema is None:
187 # Initialize with first valid value (No SMA seed for this specific variant usually,
188 # or just use value itself)
189 ema = val
190 else:
191 # EMA = Price * Alpha + Prev * (1-Alpha)
192 ema = val * alpha + ema * (1.0 - alpha)
193
194 results.append(ema)
195
196 return results
197​
198 # =============================================================================
199 # IPO: _calculate_macd (Helper)
200 # =============================================================================
201 # [Process] ShortEMA - LongEMA.
202 # =============================================================================
203 def _calculate_macd(self, candles, short_p, long_p):
204 ema_s = self._calculate_ema_candles(candles, short_p)
205 ema_l = self._calculate_ema_candles(candles, long_p)
206
207 diff = []
208 for i in range(len(candles)):
209 if ema_s[i] is None or ema_l[i] is None:
210 diff.append(None)
211 else:
212 diff.append(ema_s[i] - ema_l[i])
213 return diff
214​
215 # =============================================================================
216 # IPO: _calculate_ema_candles (Helper)
217 # =============================================================================
218 # [Process] Standard Price EMA. Seed with SMA.
219 # =============================================================================
220 def _calculate_ema_candles(self, candles, period):
221 results = []
222 alpha = 2.0 / (period + 1.0)
223 ema = None
224
225 # Pre-calculate SMA seed?
226 # Standard approach: First Period bars -> SMA. Then EMA.
227
228 running_sum = 0.0
229
230 for i in range(len(candles)):
231 close = candles[i]['close']
232
233 # Phase A: Accumulate for SMA Seed
234 if i < period - 1:
235 running_sum += close
236 results.append(None)
237 continue
238
239 # Phase B: Calculate SMA Seed
240 if i == period - 1:
241 running_sum += close
242 ema = running_sum / period
243 results.append(ema)
244 continue
245
246 # Phase C: EMA Calculation
247 ema = close * alpha + ema * (1.0 - alpha)
248 results.append(ema)
249
250 return results
251​
252​
253# =============================================================================
254# Static Wrapper Function
255# =============================================================================
256def calculate(candles, macd_short=23, macd_long=50, cycle_period=10):
257 stc = SchaffTrendCycle(macd_short, macd_long, cycle_period)
258 stc.calculate(candles)
259 return stc.values
